content: the perfect fit raglan sweater **please note this document does not contain row by row instructions with stitch counts it is intended to act as a guide to create a fully customized raglan sweater that can be adjusted to suit any body type and size you are free to sell your created items and may even share this document with a friend as i am making it available for free you can direct questions to meghansteel@outlook com just put the name of the garment in the title of your email you can also follow the designer on instagram @meghanbetty where posts involve only crochet items and dog pictures and the occasional landscape thank you for your attention i hope you enjoy making your own perfect fit raglan sweater ** abbreviations fsc - foundation single_crochet single_crochet single_crochet double_crochet - double_crochet chain - chain sl slip_stitch yarn used in example lion brand mandala in chimera -you can substitute any dk aran or worsted weight yarn depending on how thick you want the final product i recommend a self-striping yarn unless you want more control over each color change -if using mandala you will need at least 3 cakes this will allow you to make sleeves that have the same color the example sweater took less than 2 and ½ cakes or about 1200 yrd larger sweaters may require more cakes better to buy too many cakes than too few hook used in example 5 0 mm -since i am not giving a stitch count there is no gauge use whatever size hook results in your preferred size for stitches on a sweater using your selected yarn if you want to make a test swatch the primary stitch pattern is alternating single_crochet and double_crochet other supplies stitch markers scissors a yarn needle note chains at the start of each row do not count as stitches the slip_stitch also does not count as a stitch when you start the next row do not stitch into the area created by the slip_stitch your first stitch will be placed into the stitch created by the final single_crochet or double_crochet from the previous round you will end each round by stitching into the same stitch where you had placed your slip_stitch step one create the yoke this top-down sweater pattern starts with a yoke or the collar and shoulder portions of the sweater this means that you will be able to try on the sweater as you go rather than waiting until you ve sewn up each individual piece you will want to do this at regular intervals to see if you need to backtrack or find out when to start decreasing the yoke for this specific sweater is known as a raglan which just means that increases are done at the corners rather than evenly around the yoke while a traditional raglan yoke has a square shape this pattern results in a pentagon to give it a v-shape on the front you can start your sweater
